Award.AwardTitle: NSF NPGI Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2016
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF National Plant Genome Initiative Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2016. The fellowship supports a research and training plan and also presents a plan to broaden participation in biology. The title of the research and training plan for this fellowship to Dr. Alice MacQueen is "Genomics of yield variation and physiology of genotype-by-environment interactions in common bean." The host institution for the fellowship is the University of Texas at Austin and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Tom Juenger.

Common bean (Phaseolus vulgaris) is the most consumed source of plant protein worldwide and is a particularly important source of protein in the developing world. A question of pressing importance is how important crop traits, such as protein or yield, were influenced by interaction of genes with the environment, so called GXE interactions. Common bean was domesticated to grow in a wide variety of environments and is thus an excellent candidate to explore how crop traits are determined by GXE interactions. An extensive dataset of over 500 common bean varieties grown at 36 locations across the United States over 34 years links bean traits in different environments. This research project leverages these historical datasets and will document genetic variation in common bean, thus providing an exciting opportunity to connect the traits to their genetic drivers. Undergraduate students will be trained in cutting edge genomic analysis and the public will learn about plant genomics through outreach activities with the Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center.

This project combines experiments and computational analyses to determine the interactions of GXE on yield variation and other traits of common bean. New association mapping populations will be produced, and these will be directly connected to historically robust datasets containing phenotype and yield data for common bean. The genetics of yield variation will be determined through genome-wide association approaches, both for regions with genomic variation between varieties and genomic regions fixed by local adaptation between bean races. The project will test for differential expression and physiology between varieties with and without GxE in response to specific climate drivers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Here's how you may have eaten the common bean species: as refried beans, as baked beans, as kidney bean salad, or as a black bean chili. Eating common bean can improve your health: the USDA counts beans as both a vegetable and a protein, and research has found that eating common bean may help people manage their weight and increase their longevity. If you remember nothing else from this report, know that we should all be eating more beans.

 

Common bean is also a vital food crop: it is the most consumed plant protein source worldwide, it provides food security and nutrition in the developing world, and it could decrease agricultural inputs and carbon footprints in the developed world.

 

In agriculture, identifying natural variants, or alleles, of genes that improve agricultural yield in specific environments is essential for the continued improvement of these crops. This is particularly true as climates shift and climate variability increases - many crops have been developed to perform well in ideal growing environments, and their yields can be reduced by extreme weather events. This project aimed to find the genetic variants that increase common bean yield across many different types of North American bean production environments.

 

In this research project, I used an extensive dataset of over 500 common bean varieties in the United States and Canada known as the Cooperative Dry Bean Nursery (CDBN) dataset. Bean breeders have been collecting yield and other descriptions of bean traits for 20 to 50 bean varieties a year, at 10 to 20 locations, for the past 70 years (see the CDBN image). This includes environments as diverse as California, Nebraska, New York, and Saskatchewan. I obtained seed from 348 entries in the CDBN grown between 1981 and 2018. I then used genotyping-by-sequencing technology to obtain information on 1.2 million positions in the genome with two different DNA base pairs present in different CDBN individuals ? a.k.a., they had a single nucleotide polymorphism, or SNP, at those 1.2 million positions. I then linked this SNP data to the trait data in the CDBN using genome-wide association methods. I also had seed from these entries grown in Puerto Rico to create a seed bank for all of the varieties linked to this dataset, not just the commercially released varieties (see the CDBN wall image).

 

I used the trait data collected in the CDBN and the SNP data I generated to find variants of genes that affected traits from the CDBN, including seed yield, the number of days to flowering, and 20 other traits. It is fairly uncommon to use this kind of trait dataset to do genetics, so I first showed that the CDBN traits could be used to do genetic analyses. I made the analysis and the SNP data publicly available online at GitHub, and prepared a publication which is currently available on bioRxiv. I also found that chromosome one of the common bean genome had two major regions with genetic variation that affected 11-14 of these traits.

 

I also combined the trait and SNP data with daily weather data from the common bean growing seasons at these diverse locations over the past 35 years. I used these three types of data to find genetic variation that improved yield in different groups of environments, defined by similarity in the daily weather data during the growing season. I found genetic variation that affects bean yields differently in environments that experience heavy rainfall events early in the growing season, compared to environments that do not. I am writing a publication of these results and plan to make this analysis available online at GitHub once that publication is under peer review. Making these analyses public will facilitate researchers interested in implementing this analysis in other crop species.

 

Overall, this project showed that we can add genomic data to large multi-environment trials of crop species and use these trials to uncover variants of genes and genomic regions that affect crop yield in specific environments. It provides a starting point for future work in this and other crop species to explore the genetics of traits evaluated in large multi-environment trials. This, in turn, could improve crop yields in stressful and variable environments without affecting yields in the best crop production environments.
